comments.body: Can we add here a message what should be installed (to help a user to find quicker solution)?

comments.body: Why  here not to cache it?
because we need it only internally when we run the loops in all the PyROOT CMakeLists.txt
I was worried if it is visible outside of cmake/modules/SearchRootCoreDeps.cmake.
when I built everything was fine. Do you want me to put it back anyway?
but then why in line 43 and 102 it is done in different way? It is confusing...
because I forgot to remove it :) just changed

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +56,60 @@      set(PYTHON_VERSION_MAJOR "${Python2_VERSION_MAJOR}" CACHE INTERNAL "" FORCE)
      set(PYTHON_VERSION_MINOR "${Python2_VERSION_MINOR}" CACHE INTERNAL "" FORCE)
      set(PYTHON_UNDER_VERSION_STRING "${Python2_VERSION_MAJOR}_${Python2_VERSION_MINOR}")
      set(NUMPY_FOUND ${Python2_NumPy_FOUND} CACHE INTERNAL "" FORCE)
      set(NUMPY_INCLUDE_DIRS "${Python2_NumPy_INCLUDE_DIRS}" CACHE INTERNAL "" FORCE)

comments.body:
I think we should be a bit more informative, just adding this condition means that the user could see that CMake found a e.g. Python2.6 installation, and if there is no Python3, an error will appear saying "No Python 2 or 3 were found", which would be confusing since they saw we found their Python2.6. Or they expect that we will build with both Python2.6 and Python3, and in the end they only see the libraries generated for Python3 with no more information.

I believe we should first give a message here saying something like "Ignoring Python2 installation: unsupported version X.Y (version>=2.7 required)". And later, if no suitable Python2 nor Python3 is found, say `message(FATAL_ERROR "No supported Python 2 or 3 were found")`
Why do we need `Python_EXECUTABLE` here now?
Because Python_EXECUTABLE is the "modern" version of PYTHON_EXECUTABLE (which is deprecated)
(so annoying, CMake guys looks like were multiplying all possible naming cases :D )

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +11,15 @@if(CMAKE_VERSION VERSION_GREATER_EQUAL 3.14)

  if(PYTHON_EXECUTABLE OR Python_EXECUTABLE)
    # - Check if the PYTHON_EXECUTABLE deprecated variable or Python_EXECUTABLE
    # was passed by the user; if so, PyROOT will be built with a single version

comments.body: So we don't offer the option to the user to specify `Python_EXECUTABLE` anymore?

It's open to discussion, I have no strong opinion honestly. I added it in the last PR because it was used internally, now it's not used anymore and for backward compatibility the only one needed is ```PYTHON_EXECUTABLE```.
Ok, for me let's just use PYTHON_EXECUTABLE.

  if(PYTHON_EXECUTABLE)
    # - Check if the PYTHON_EXECUTABLE deprecated variable
    # was passed by the user; if so, PyROOT will be built with a single version
